docs.title: Documentation for pynxtools-ellips
docs.text:
pynxtools-ellips is a free and open-source data software for harmonizing ellipsometry data and metadata for research data management using NeXus, implemented with the goal to make scientific research data FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable).

pynxtools-ellips, which is a plugin for pynxtools, provides a tool for reading data from (currently Woollam VASE) proprietary and open data formats from technology partners and the wider ellipsometry community. The tool standardizes these data such that it is compliant with the NeXus application definitions NXoptical_spectroscopy and its extension NXellipsometry. pynxtools-ellips is developed both as a standalone reader and as a tool within NOMAD, which is the open-source data management platform for materials science we are developing with FAIRmat.

pynxtools-ellips solves the challenge of using heterogeneous and unfindable data formats which is common in the field of ellipsometry.

pynxtools-ellips is useful for scientists from the ellipsometry community that deal with heterogeneous data, for technology partners and data providers looking for ways to make their data FAIRer, and for research groups that want to organize their data using NeXus and NOMAD.

Contact

docs.title: Data from Woollam instruments
docs.text:
The reader supports ellipsometry files exported from Woollam instruments in the .dat format.

The reader can be found here.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
An example dataset can be found here.

The example conversion can be run with the following command:

dataconverter --reader ellips --nxdl NXellipsometry eln_data.yaml --output SiO2onSi.nxs

docs.title: Development guide
docs.text: This tutorial will guide you through on how to set up a working environment for developing pynxtools-ellips.

docs.title: What should you know before this tutorial?
docs.text:
• You should read the guide on getting started with pynxtools.
  • You should read the installation tutorial.

docs.title: What you will know at the end of this tutorial?
docs.text:
You will know

  • how to setup your environment for developing pynxtools-ellips
  • how to make changes to the software
  • how to test the software
  • how to contribute on GitHub
  • how to use pynxtools-ellips as a NOMAD plugin

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Structure of the pynxtools-ellips repository

The software tools are located inside src/pynxtools_ellips. They are shipped with unit tests located in tests.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
It is recommended to use python 3.12 with a dedicated virtual environment for this package. Learn how to manage python versions and virtual environments. We recommend using uv, an extremely fast Python package and project manager. In this tutorial, you will find parallel descriptions, using either uv or a more classical approach using venv and pip.

Start by creating a virtual environment:

uvvenv

uv is capable of creating a virtual environment and install the required Python version at the same time.

uv venv --python 3.12

Note that you will need to install the Python version manually beforehand.

python -m venv .venv

That command creates a new virtual environment in a directory called .venv.

docs.title: Development installation
docs.text:
We start by cloning the repository:

git clone https://github.com/FAIRmat-NFDI/pynxtools-ellips.git \\
    --branch main \\
    --recursive pynxtools-ellips
cd pynxtools-ellips

Next, we install the package in editable mode (together with its dependencies):

uvpip 
uv pip install -e ".[dev]"

Note that you will need to install the Python version manually beforehand.

pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -e ".[dev]"

docs.title: Linting and formatting
docs.text:
We are using ruff and mypy for linting, formatting, and type checking. It is recommended to use the pre-commit hook available for ruff which formats the code and checks the linting before making a Git commit.

Install the precommit by running

pre-commit install

from the root of this repository.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
There exist unit tests for the software written in pytest which can be used as follows:

pytest -sv tests

docs.title: Editing the documentation
docs.text:
We are using mkdocs for the documentation. If you edit the documentation, you can build it locally. For this, you need to install an additional set of dependencies:

uvpip 
uv pip install -e ".[docs]"

pip install -e ".[docs]"

You can then serve the documentation locally by running

mkdocs serve

docs.title: Contributing to the package on GitHub
docs.text: Once you are happy with the changes, please commit them on a separate branch and create a pull request on GitHub. We run a number of GitHub actions that check the correct linting, run the tests in an isolated environment, and build the documentation. Once these pass and a peer review of the code has occurred, your code will be accepted.

docs.title: Developing pynxtools-ellips as a NOMAD plugin
docs.text: If you plan to contribute to the NOMAD plugin functionality of pynxtools-ellips, it often makes sense to use the NOMAD development environment called nomad-distro-dev. You can learn more in the NOMAD documentation.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: If you face any issues with the tool or when setting up the development environment, please create a new Github Issue.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
It is recommended to use python 3.12 with a dedicated virtual environment for this package. Learn how to manage python versions and virtual environments.

There are many alternatives to managing virtual environments and package dependencies (requirements). We recommend using uv, an extremely fast Python package and project manager. In this tutorial, you will find parallel descriptions, using either uv or a more classical approach using venv and pip.

Start by creating a virtual environment:

uvvenv

uv is capable of creating a virtual environment and install the required Python version at the same time.

uv venv --python 3.12

Note that you will need to install the Python version manually beforehand.

python -m venv .venv

That command creates a new virtual environment in a directory called .venv.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install the latest stable version of this package from PyPI with

uvpip 
uv pip install pynxtools-ellips

pip install pynxtools-ellips

You can also install the latest development version with

uvpip 
uv pip install git+https://github.com/FAIRmat-NFDI/pynxtools-ellips.git

pip install git+https://github.com/FAIRmat-NFDI/pynxtools-ellips.git

docs.title: How to install pynxtools-ellips with NOMAD
docs.text: To use pynxtools-ellips with NOMAD, simply install it in the same environment as the nomad-lab package. NOMAD will recognize pynxtools-ellips as a plugin automatically. In addition, NOMAD will install a schema for NeXus application definitions.

docs.text: That's it! You can now use pynxtools-ellips!
